dublinCore.dc:title: 114 HR 1428 IH: Judicial Redress Act of 2015
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Sensenbrenner (for himself and Mr. Conyers) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To extend Privacy Act remedies to citizens of certified states, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Judicial Redress Act of 2015.

section.header: Extension of Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries

subsection.text: With respect to covered records, a covered person may bring a civil action against an agency and obtain civil remedies, in the same manner, to the same extent, and subject to the same limitations, including exemptions and exceptions, as an individual may bring and obtain with respect to records under—

paragraph.text: section 552a(g)(1)(D) of title 5, United States Code, but only with respect to disclosures intentionally or willfully made in violation of section 552a(b) of such title; and
subparagraphs (A) and (B) of section 552a(g)(1) of title 5, United States Code, but such an action may only be brought against a designated Federal agency or component.

subsection.text: The remedies set forth in subsection (a) are the exclusive remedies available to a covered person under this section.

subsection.header: Application of the Privacy Act with respect to a covered person
subsection.text: For purposes of a civil action described in subsection (a), a covered person shall have the same rights, and be subject to the same limitations, including exemptions and exceptions, as an individual has and is subject to under section 552a of title 5, United States Code, when pursuing the civil remedies described in paragraphs (1) and (2) of subsection (a).

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Secretary of Homeland Security, designate a foreign country or regional economic integration organization, or member country of such organization, as a covered country for purposes of this section if—

subparagraph.text: the country or regional economic integration organization, or member country of such organization, has entered into an agreement with the United States that provides for appropriate privacy protections for information shared for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting, or prosecuting criminal offenses; or

the Attorney General has determined that the country or regional economic integration organization, or member country of such organization, has effectively shared information with the United States for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting, or prosecuting criminal offenses and has appropriate privacy protections for such shared information.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General may, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Secretary of Homeland Security, revoke the designation of a foreign country or regional economic integration organization, or member country of such organization, as a covered country if the Attorney General determines that such designated covered country—

subparagraph.text: is not complying with the agreement described under paragraph (1)(A);
no longer meets the requirements for designation under paragraph (1)(B); or
impedes the transfer of information (for purposes of reporting or preventing unlawful activity) to the United States by a private entity or person.

subsection.header: Designation of designated Federal agency or component

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall determine whether an agency or component thereof is a designated Federal agency or component for purposes of this section. The Attorney General shall not designate any agency or component thereof other than the Department of Justice or a component of the Department of Justice without the concurrence of the head of the relevant agency, or of the agency to which the component belongs.
The Attorney General may determine that an agency or component of an agency is a designated Federal agency or component for purposes of this section, if—

subparagraph.text: the Attorney General determines that information exchanged by such agency with a covered country is within the scope of an agreement referred to in subsection (d)(1)(A); or

with respect to a country or regional economic integration organization, or member country of such organization, that has been designated as a covered country under subsection (d)(1)(B), the Attorney General determines that designating such agency or component thereof is in the law enforcement interests of the United States.

subsection.text: The Attorney General shall publish each determination made under subsections (d) and (e). Such determination shall not be subject to judicial or administrative review.
The United States District Court for the District of Columbia shall have exclusive jurisdiction over any claim arising under this section.

paragraph.text: The term agency has the meaning given that term in section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code.
The term covered country means a country or regional economic integration organization, or member country of such organization, designated in accordance with subsection (d).
The term covered person means a natural person (other than an individual) who is a citizen of a covered country.
The term covered record has the same meaning for a covered person as a record has for an individual under section 552a of title 5, United States Code, once the covered record is transferred—

subparagraph.text: by a public authority of, or private entity within, a country or regional economic organization, or member country of such organization, which at the time the record is transferred is a covered country; and
to a designated Federal agency or component for purposes of preventing, investigating, detecting, or prosecuting criminal offenses.

paragraph.text: The term designated Federal agency or component means a Federal agency or component of an agency designated in accordance with subsection (e).
The term individual has the meaning given that term in section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed to waive any applicable privilege or require the disclosure of classified information. Upon an agency’s request, the district court shall review in camera and ex parte any submission by the agency in connection with this subsection.
This Act shall take effect 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.
